review_title: Nobel company mission w/ unreasonable expectations
pros: Outwardly CEO, is a very noble mission, with a great deal of altruistic expectations. However, this mission gets lost daily in its everyday cultural practices.
cons: The hours are long, work-life balance sucks, and in most cases the performance expectations are greatly mis-aligned with the support and capabilities of the organization. There is a great deal of favoritism from management, and the upward mobility is based on who you know or likes you in the company, not effort or performance. This can be very defeating.

pros: Most employees have a true passion for the work they do, including management at all levels. Evidence-based, data-driven culture. Very creative and risk-savvy management not afraid to make bold decisions and quickly capitalize on new organizational opportunities.
cons:
For a company this size, a ridiculously small amount of resources are invested in recruitment, hiring, and HR. This leads to a host of other problems, like poor hiring decisions. For example, the immediate supervisor of a posted position must serve as her own recruiter, screener, interviewer, and salary negotiator--all while attempting to maintain her normal workload. Senior management knows this and seems to think it's the way businesses with 150+ people and 10+ offices normally operate (it's not).

In addition, many systems and processes in place are extremely inefficient, and fixes come very slowly due to lack of resources (and because everyone is so busy trying to work within the inefficient systems already in place). C-level management, while clearly well-intentioned, has a very narrow perspective, with no experience running other companies this size. Best practices that would be no-brainers at most organizations are often not considered necessary. This comes at a huge expense to the long-term health of the organization.

pros: Supports an important mission and oft-overlooked population
cons: Shifts in leadership infrastructure created challenges during my tenure but these were resolved and ultimately seem to have strengthened the organization

pros: Work Earn income no morals

job_title: Site Director in New Orleans, LA
pros: Flexibility is not bad at CEO compared to other places.
cons: Pay can be a lot better for the work load.

pros:
Great mission
Strong results
Reputation
Talented and committed staff
Adaptable to change
cons:
Leadership is immature and unprofessional. Most don't have management skills and don't care about their staff. Always focusing on outside image and networking instead of managing the staff and program. Bad at admitting failure. People at top always looking to assign blame outward or below. Diversity only at the bottom. People in leadership are all of the same backgrounds and try to pad diversity into lower level positions.

Burnout is a given. People work hard for little recognition; you only hear from the top when something goes wrong. Priorities shift fast there's always pressure to respond fast and keep sacrificing more.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Front line staff tend to have each others back. Hard not to when youre all you have. Management is basically non-existent
cons: where to begin? Favoritism, sexism, colorism, white supremacist culture. Managers are so consumed with where their next contract is coming from they do not care at all about concerns or safety of both participants and staff. Why is it that a front line staff member and not a manager has to de-escalate situations with hostile clients? Pay is low, days are long, could hardly get any manager to address any issues (client pay checks, (handful of time where checks or direct deposit was late and payroll, and managers were dismissive as if clients do not rely on their daily pay), ideas are not listened to or implemented.  Mission is good but execution is horrific.

pros:
The organization has a great mission and has helped thousands of men and women get on their feet. I've seen first hand how CEO impacts the lives of participants and their families.

I learned SO much from my experience at CEO and am thankful to have had the opportunity learn and grow during my tenure.
cons: I'm not sure management truly understands the work that staff put in. There is a feeling that management doesn't trust staff and is very guarded with information, while they want to have full access to staff and their individual work.

review_title: Insiders Club or it isn't our fault we keep hiring the wrong people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The company's main office us easily accessible by mass transit.
cons: What seemingly started out as a noble idea to help people with criminal convictions get and keep jobs has become something very different. Yes, in NYC we still work with a steadily decreasing number of men. Some of whom gain real employment. The primary emphasis is not NYC anymore  more. With the opening of offices in California, Oklahoma and upstate New York . The majority of resources are going to creating a bigger kingdom for the leadership and not to helping people.

pros: If allowed to do your job unobstructed you can make an impact on people who truly need your help
cons: Management takes advice only from people with Graduate Degrees or better.  I have witnessed people given pay raises who have not one clue what they are doing because they have never suffered through what our Participants are going through.  Promotions, favoritism, politics are HUGE. If you are a minority you will probably get passed up for promotion.  If you have actually done time and can identify with our participants, your opinion does not count and your input will be dismissed for that of someone who is College Educated and Data-Driven.  You promote people who suck up to you as opposed to those that are actually contributing to the organization.

review_title: Great mission, good place to work
pros: The company's performance culture is outstanding.  Emphasis is placed on outcomes and you are given adequate tools to reach your goals.  Leadership is smart and strategic.  Pay is good, not great. Line staff and first line supervisors have a great relationship.  The company culture is collaborative rather than competitive.
cons: Leadership can be somewhat out of touch.  Senior leadership is very focused on strategic planning and the public perception of the company that they sometimes lose sight of the people that make the whole thing work.
